title: 110_s2471
content: The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" is the short title of this Act. It aims to reform the USERRA complaint process. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints. It requires the Secretary to notify complainants of their rights within 5 days and offer technical assistance upon request. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints. The Secretary must provide technical assistance upon request to potential claimants and their employers. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code to expedite complaint resolution. The Secretary must complete required actions within 90 days of receiving a complaint. Referrals to the Attorney General must be expedited within 15 days of the Secretary receiving a request. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" requires the Secretary to complete complaint resolution within 90 days. Referrals to the Attorney General must be made within 15 days of receiving a request. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" mandates that the Secretary must resolve complaints within 90 days and refer them to the Attorney General within 15 days of receiving a request. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" requires the Secretary to refer complaints to the Attorney General within 15 days of receiving a request. The Attorney General must make a decision on representation within 45 days of receiving the referral. The Attorney General must decide whether to represent the person within 45 days of receiving a referral. The Special Counsel must also make a decision within the same timeframe after receiving a referral. The Special Counsel must decide within 45 days of receiving a referral whether to initiate an action and represent a person before the Merit Systems Protection Board, notifying the person of the decision. SEC. 3. EXPANSION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS WITH RESPECT TO ENFORCEMENT OF USERRA. The Secretary of Defense will now include the number of cases reviewed through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve in the annual report. The Secretary of Defense will include the number of cases reviewed by the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve in the annual report, including cases involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment. The Secretary of Defense will report the number of cases reviewed by the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve in the annual report, including cases involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment, as well as cases related to disability issues. The Secretary of Defense will report the number of cases reviewed by the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve in the annual report, including cases related to disability issues and employment or reemployment of individuals with disabilities. In subsection (a), amendments are made to require reporting to various entities including Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. Additionally, a new subsection is added for a Quarterly Report by the Comptroller General. The amendment includes replacing "transmit to the Congress" with "submit to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel." A new subsection requires the Comptroller General to provide quarterly reports to the mentioned entities. The Comptroller General must submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The report should include the number of cases where the Secretary did not meet requirements and cases where referrals were not made within the required time period. The Comptroller General must submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The report should include the number of cases where the Secretary did not meet requirements and cases where referrals were not made within the required time period, as specified in various sections of the title. The Comptroller General must submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The report should include the number of cases where referrals were not made within the required time period or did not meet the necessary requirements. The Special Counsel received referrals under section 4323(a) and 4324(a) but did not meet the requirements. The Secretary must coordinate with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for uniform data categorization. The Special Counsel received referrals under section 4323(a) and 4324(a) but did not meet the requirements. The Secretary must coordinate with the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel to ensure uniform data categorization. The Secretary must coordinate with the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel to ensure uniform data categorization in reports and electronic access to case files. The amendments made by this section apply to reports required under section 4332. Special Counsel, including the Secretary, Secretary of Defense, Attorney General, and Special Counsel, have electronic access to case files reviewed under this chapter. The amendments made by this section will apply to reports required under section 4332 after the enactment of this Act.
